description: The underlying reason outlined in the post is that attempting to defrag solid-state drives (SSDs) or NVMe drives can lead to more problems than it resolves, in addition to negatively impacting the lifespan of the SSD. This misconception stems from the traditional view of defragmentation processes that apply to hard disk drives (HDDs) but do not suit SSDs due to their unique architecture. SSDs leverage flash memory, which allows them to access data instantly regardless of its physical location, rendering defragmentation unnecessary and counterproductive. Consequently, this practice can generate excessive write cycles, which ultimately reduces the operational lifespan of SSDs. The post encourages system administrators to reference resources, such as an article from Crucial, for guidance on proper SSD maintenance and management practices regarding defragmentation.
